response.answer_text: No! Old 32-bit CPUs don’t have new security features like NX-bit or encryption hardware which makes them inherently a little more vulnerable. However even on the same platform with all same features available a 64-bit program is generally safer from attacks than a 32-bit one In Windows, 64-bit drivers are required to be signed, so they must come from a trusted party and be tested carefully before releasing. You can’t install unsigned drivers like on 32-bit Windows unless you explicitly disable that on boot64-bit Windows kernel has the ability to do hot patching. That means you can install kernel updates without any computer reboot or program restart and enjoy the more secure kernel instantly. 32-bit kernel is only about 30% hot-patchable. 64-bit kernel also supports PatchGuard which is not available in 32-bit version.Hardware DEP is turned on by default on 64-bit WindowsModern OSes use address space layout randomization for preventing some types of exploitation. It works by putting the program code/stack/data… in random position each time the process started. In a 32-bit address space you don’t have much address space to choose. If your program uses most of its 2/3 GB of space then it can’t be moved anywhere. In a 64-bit address space you have 4 billion more choicesOn the flip side, as well as avoiding address space exhaustion problems, a security feature known as ASLR works much better in 64-bit applications than in 32-bit applications, so 64-bit Firefox will be slightly more secure. Firefox 64-bit for Windows can take advantage of more memory In addition, the 64-bit version of Chrome includes a 64-bit version of Adobe Flash. Google has worked with Adobe to improve Flash’s protections against various type of attack, and these exploit mitigations are more effective on 64-bit versions of Chrome. There are other ways Chrome behaves more securely on 64-bit versions of Windows, too, but Google doesn’t have a slick page explaining all of them. For example, a comment in this bug report notes that the 64-bit version of Chrome provides additional protection from third-party software–like antivirus programs that shouldn’t be touching the browser–hooking into Chrome’s sandboxed processes You Should Upgrade to 64-bit Chrome. It’s More Secure, Stable, and Speedy Finally, on 64-bit, our defense in depth security mitigations such as Partition Alloc are able to far more effectively defend against vulnerabilities that rely on controlling the memory layout of objects. 64 bits of awesome: 64-bit Windows Support, now in Stable! no… it's like asking “is this 10 unit high wall safer than that 100 unit one?” if all other parameters are same(like same material, thickness etc)… no… 32bit itself has no advantages over 64bit, but 32bit processors are a tiny bit different story…because they've been out for so long most of their flaws are known… but 64bit is safer in the sense that 32bit stuff is getting left behind and abandoned…kinda like you don't see 16bit programs anymore…64bit is actively protected right now, so when a flaw is found there are big teams who'll begin fixing it…
